column1: Tartagal (Spanish pronunciation: [taɾtaˈɣal]) is a city in the north of the province of Salta
column3: 365 km from the provincial capital. It has over 60
column5: and it is the head town of the General José de San Martín Department (with about 3/4 of its population). It is crossed by the river of the same name.

column1: Tartagal is located in an area of major economic importance for the province
column2: within Argentina's second largest natural gas reservoir
column3: and at a crossroads for trade in the Mercosur (being only 55 km from the border with Bolivia and 100 km from Paraguay). The area produces 25% of the oil and about 16% of the natural gas in Argentina.

column1: The social composition of Tartagal is characterized by its cultural diversity. There are seven aboriginal ethnic groups that reside in Tartagal: wichís (or weenhayek)
column6: chulupíes and Aymaras. Another important element of its social structure is the migratory component that is added to its population. Because of it is so close to Bolivia
column7: a high percentage of its inhabitants are of Bolivian origin. Tartagal was the main destination of immigration of the peasant-livestock population of the east (commonly known as "Chaco") that settled
column9: in neighborhoods surrounding the city. It also has important foreign communities including: Christian Levantines (of Syrian-Lebanese origin)

column6: surpassed only by the provincial capital and by San Ramón de la Nueva Orán.

column1: Tartagal derives from the tártago plant (Euphorbia lathyris
column2: a kind of spurge). The area of modern Tartagal appears with this name in legal documents for the first time in 1853.  At the time the area belonged to the Tarija Department
column3: Bolivia. The foundation date of the town
column6: 1924; the municipality was created soon afterwards
column7: and Tartagal attained city status only on September 22

Since 1926 the state-owned oil company YPF employed or indirectly supported most of the local population. In 1992 the company was privatized (becoming Repsol-YPF) and 90% of its workers were fired
